body:
Comment 2 by **alski85**: 
Understood about not supporting 5.x as indicated in the issue tracker.  Go 1.0.3 I
believe has the same caveat, I was rather surprised that it built correctly.  I am only
building out of curiosity - for testing and bug tracking.  
If go 1.1 cannot support rhel5, this is not really an issue as far as I'm concerned -
although I do feel it's some size of the enterprise market.  Since 'go' was not in
existence even at the time that RHEL5 was released, it's not necessarily a package that
should remain as outdated as the OS for some legacy reasons - unless of course that has
become a requirement. 
I only wanted to note the issue in the case that this is truly a bug in the code change,
rather than a purposefully designed change.  I don't keep up on all of the happenings
and changes as I'd like, but I didn't recall an explicit note/reason/announcement
regarding this.  I understand also it's not the developer's job to provide this
necessarily, as it's covered in the 'not supported' realm, but I'm curious nonetheless.

Thank you for your time and reply.
